Equality of orthogonal transvection group and elementary orthogonal transvection group

Pratyusha Chattopadhyay
Statistics and Mathematics Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore 560 059, India

2010 MSC: 11C20, 13C10, 14L35, 15A24, 15A54, 15A63, 20H25

Key words: elementary orthogonal group, transvection, elementary transvection

Abstract: H. Bass defined orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module and elementary orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module with a hyperbolic direct summand. We also have the notion of relative orthogonal transvection group and relative elementary orthogonal transvection group with respect to an ideal of the ring. According to the definition of Bass relative elementary orthogonal transvection group is a subgroup of relative orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module with hyperbolic direct summand. Here we show that these two groups are the same in the case when the orthogonal module splits locally.

1 Introduction

In Section 5 of [10] L.N. Vaserstein proved that first row of an elementary linear matrix of even size (bigger than or equal to 4) is the same as the first row of a symplectic matrix of the same size w.r.t. an alternating form. This result motivated us to prove that the orbit of a unimodular row of even size under the action of elementary linear group is same as the orbit of a unimodular row of same size under the action of elementary symplectic group (see Theorem 4.1, [4]); we also proved a relative (to an ideal of the ring) version of this result (see Theorem 5.5, [4]). Generalising this result in the setting of finitely generated projective modules involving the transvection groups as defined by H. Bass, we proved that in the case of a symplectic module with a hyperbolic direct summand the orbits of any unimodular element from the symplectic module, under the actions of elementary linear transvection group and the elementary symplectic transvection group coincide(see Theorem 6.1, [5]). While proving the above result on equality of orbits of unimodular elements of symplectic modules, we observed that in the relative case to an ideal of the ring, the equality holds between the linear transvection group and the elementary linear transvection group (see Proposition 4.10, [5]). We also noticed that in the relative case to an ideal of the ring, the symplectic transvection group and the elementary symplectic transvection group coincide (see Theorem 5.23, [5]). In the absolute case the equalities for linear transvection group, symplectic transvection group, and orthogonal transvection group with the corresponding elementary transvection groups were proved in [2]. In view of the above results it is natural to ask whether the equality of orthogonal transvection group and elementary orthogonal transvection group holds in the relative case to an ideal of the ring. In this article we prove the equality of these two groups in the case when the orthogonal module splits locally.

Definition 2.10.

The group EO2‚Äãn1‚Äã(R,I)superscriptsubscriptEO2ùëõ1ùëÖùêº{\rm EO}_{2n}^{1}(R,I) is the subgroup of EO2‚Äãn‚Äã(R)subscriptEO2ùëõùëÖ{\rm EO}_{2n}(R) generated by the elements of the form o‚Äãe1‚Äãi‚Äã(a)ùëúsubscriptùëí1ùëñùëéoe_{1i}(a) and o‚Äãej‚Äã1‚Äã(x)ùëúsubscriptùëíùëó1ùë•oe_{j1}(x), where a‚ààRùëéùëÖa\in R, x‚ààIùë•ùêºx\in I and 3‚â§i,j‚â§2‚Äãnformulae-sequence3ùëñùëó2ùëõ3\leq i,j\leq 2n.

In the following two lemmas we obtain some useful facts regarding elementary orthogonal groups. An analogous result in the linear case was proved in [7] and in the symplectic case was proved in the Appendix of [5].

Lemma 2.11.

Let RùëÖR be a commutative ring and IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. Then EO2‚Äãn‚Äã(R,I)‚äÜEO2‚Äãn1‚Äã(R,I)subscriptEO2ùëõùëÖùêºsuperscriptsubscriptEO2ùëõ1ùëÖùêº{\rm EO}_{2n}(R,I)\subseteq{\rm EO}_{2n}^{1}(R,I), for n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3.

Proposition 2.12.

3 Local Global Principle for Relative Elementary Group

In this section we prove Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.4 which will be used in proving the main result in the final section. In Lemma 3.4 we obtain the Local-Global Principle for an extended ideal for slightly larger group EO(R,I)2‚Äãn1{}_{2n}^{1}(R,I) than the relative group EO(R,I)2‚Äãn{}_{2n}(R,I). This group was introduced in the linear case by W. van der Kallen in [7]. The Local-Global Principle for an extended ideal in the linear, orthogonal and symplectic groups was proved in [1].

The line of arguments given in the proofs below closely follow that in the Local-Global principle for an extended ideal in the symplectic case in [5]. However, as far as the the computational details are concerned, there are substantial deviations from [5] in many steps.

Lemma 3.1.

Let RùëÖR be a commutative ring and IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. Let n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3. Proof: We prove the result using induction on rùëür, where ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon is product of rùëür many elementary generators. 4 Orthogonal Modules and Orthogonal Transvections

In this section we prove Theorem 4.22 which is the main result of this paper. We begin with a sequence of definitions.

Definition 4.1.

Let MùëÄM be an RùëÖR-module. A bilinear form on MùëÄM is a function Œ≤:M√óM‚ü∂R:ùõΩ‚ü∂ùëÄùëÄùëÖ\beta:M\times M\longrightarrow R such that Œ≤‚Äã(x,y)ùõΩùë•ùë¶\beta(x,y) is RùëÖR-linear as a function of xùë•x for fixed yùë¶y, and RùëÖR-linear as a function of yùë¶y for fixed xùë•x. The pair (M,Œ≤)ùëÄùõΩ(M,\beta) is called bilinear form module over RùëÖR. Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is called an inner product if it satisfies non-degeneracy condition, i.e, the natural map induced by Œ≤ùõΩ\beta from P‚ü∂P‚àó‚ü∂ùëÉsuperscriptùëÉP\longrightarrow P^{*} is an isomorphism. In this case the pair (M,Œ≤)ùëÄùõΩ(M,\beta) is called inner product module over RùëÖR. A bilinear form or inner product Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is called symmetric if Œ≤‚Äã(x,y)=Œ≤‚Äã(y,x)ùõΩùë•ùë¶ùõΩùë¶ùë•\beta(x,y)=\beta(y,x), for all x,y‚ààMùë•ùë¶ùëÄx,y\in M. An inner product module (M,Œ≤)ùëÄùõΩ(M,\beta) will be called inner product space if MùëÄM is finitely generated and projective over RùëÖR.

Definition 4.2.

An orthogonal RùëÖR-module is a pair (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle), where PùëÉP is a finitely generated projective RùëÖR-module of even rank and ‚ü®,‚ü©:P√óP‚ü∂R\langle,\rangle:P\times P\longrightarrow R is a non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form. This is also known as symmetric inner product space.

Definition 4.3.

Let (P1,‚ü®,‚ü©1)(P_{1},\langle,\rangle_{1}) and (P2,‚ü®,‚ü©2)(P_{2},\langle,\rangle_{2}) be two orthogonal RùëÖR-modules. Their orthogonal sum is the pair (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle), where P=P1‚äïP2ùëÉdirect-sumsubscriptùëÉ1subscriptùëÉ2P=P_{1}\oplus P_{2} and the inner product is defined by ‚ü®(p1,p2),(q1,q2)‚ü©=‚ü®p1,q1‚ü©1+‚ü®p2,q2‚ü©2subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2subscriptùëû1subscriptùëû2subscriptsubscriptùëù1subscriptùëû11subscriptsubscriptùëù2subscriptùëû22\langle(p_{1},p_{2}),(q_{1},q_{2})\rangle=\langle p_{1},q_{1}\rangle_{1}+\langle p_{2},q_{2}\rangle_{2}.

Definition 4.4.

There is a non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form ‚ü®,‚ü©\langle,\rangle on the RùëÖR-module R‚äïR‚àódirect-sumùëÖsuperscriptùëÖR\oplus R^{*}, namely ‚ü®(a1,f1),(a2,f2)‚ü©=f2‚Äã(a1)+f1‚Äã(a2)subscriptùëé1subscriptùëì1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëì2subscriptùëì2subscriptùëé1subscriptùëì1subscriptùëé2\langle(a_{1},f_{1}),(a_{2},f_{2})\rangle=f_{2}(a_{1})+f_{1}(a_{2}). The orthogonal module R‚äïR‚àódirect-sumùëÖsuperscriptùëÖR\oplus R^{*} with this symmetric bilinear form is denoted by ‚Ñç‚Äã(R)‚ÑçùëÖ\mathbb{H}(R) and called hyperbolic plane. Note that ‚Ñçn‚Äã(R)superscript‚ÑçùëõùëÖ\mathbb{H}^{n}(R) is the orthogonal sum of nùëõn-copies of ‚Ñç‚Äã(R)‚ÑçùëÖ\mathbb{H}(R).

Definition 4.5.

An isometry of an orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is an automorphism of PùëÉP which fixes the bilinear form. The group of isometries of (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is denoted by O‚Äã(P)OùëÉ{\rm O}(P).

Definition 4.6.

Let (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) be an orthogonal module. H. Bass defined orthogonal transvection of an orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is an automorphism of the form

œÑ‚Äã(p)ùúèùëù\displaystyle\tau(p) =\displaystyle= p‚àí‚ü®u,p‚ü©‚Äãv+‚ü®v,p‚ü©‚Äãu,ùëùùë¢ùëùùë£ùë£ùëùùë¢\displaystyle p-\langle u,p\rangle v+\langle v,p\rangle u,

where u,v‚ààPùë¢ùë£ùëÉu,v\in P are isotropic, i.e, ‚ü®u,u‚ü©=‚ü®v,v‚ü©=0ùë¢ùë¢ùë£ùë£0\langle u,u\rangle=\langle v,v\rangle=0 with ‚ü®u,v‚ü©=0ùë¢ùë£0\langle u,v\rangle=0, and either uùë¢u or vùë£v is unimodular. It is easy to check that ‚ü®œÑ‚Äã(p),œÑ‚Äã(q)‚ü©=‚ü®p,q‚ü©ùúèùëùùúèùëûùëùùëû\langle\tau(p),\tau(q)\rangle=\langle p,q\rangle, i.e, œÑ‚ààO‚Äã(P)ùúèOùëÉ\tau\in{\rm O}(P) and œÑùúè\tau has an inverse œÉ‚Äã(p)=p+‚ü®u,p‚ü©‚Äãv‚àí‚ü®v,p‚ü©‚Äãuùúéùëùùëùùë¢ùëùùë£ùë£ùëùùë¢\sigma(p)=p+\langle u,p\rangle v-\langle v,p\rangle u.

The subgroup of O‚Äã(P)OùëÉ{\rm O}(P) generated by the orthogonal transvections is called orthogonal transvection group and denoted by TransO(P,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(P,\langle,\rangle) (see [3] or [6]).

Now onwards QùëÑQ will denote (R2‚äïP)direct-sumsuperscriptùëÖ2ùëÉ(R^{2}\oplus P) with induced form on (‚Ñç‚Äã(R)‚äïP)direct-sum‚ÑçùëÖùëÉ(\mathbb{H}(R)~{}\oplus~{}P), and Q‚Äã[X]ùëÑdelimited-[]ùëãQ[X] will denote (R‚Äã[X]2‚äïP‚Äã[X])direct-sumùëÖsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëã2ùëÉdelimited-[]ùëã(R[X]^{2}\oplus P[X]) with induced form on (‚Ñç‚Äã(R‚Äã[X])‚äïP‚Äã[X])direct-sum‚ÑçùëÖdelimited-[]ùëãùëÉdelimited-[]ùëã(\mathbb{H}(R[X])~{}\oplus~{}P[X]).

Definition 4.7.

The orthogonal transvections of Q=(R2‚äïP)ùëÑdirect-sumsuperscriptùëÖ2ùëÉQ=(R^{2}\oplus P) of the form

(a,b,p)ùëéùëèùëù\displaystyle(a,b,p) ‚Ü¶maps-to\displaystyle\mapsto (a,b+‚ü®p,q‚ü©,p‚àía‚Äãq),ùëéùëèùëùùëûùëùùëéùëû\displaystyle(a,b+\langle p,q\rangle,p-aq),

or of the form

(a,b,p)ùëéùëèùëù\displaystyle(a,b,p) ‚Ü¶maps-to\displaystyle\mapsto (a+‚ü®p,q‚ü©,b,p‚àíb‚Äãq),ùëéùëùùëûùëèùëùùëèùëû\displaystyle(a+\langle p,q\rangle,b,p-bq),

where a,b‚ààRùëéùëèùëÖa,b\in R and p,q‚ààPùëùùëûùëÉp,q\in P, are called elementary orthogonal transvections. Let us denote the first isometry by œÅ‚Äã(q)ùúåùëû\rho(q) and the second one by Œº‚Äã(q)ùúáùëû\mu(q). It can be verified that the elementary orthogonal transvections are orthogonal transvections on QùëÑQ. Indeed, consider (u,v)=((0,1,0),(0,0,q))ùë¢ùë£01000ùëû(u,v)=((0,1,0),(0,0,q)) to get œÅ‚Äã(q)ùúåùëû\rho(q) and consider (u,v)=((1,0,0),(0,0,q))ùë¢ùë£10000ùëû(u,v)=((1,0,0),(0,0,q)) to get Œº‚Äã(q,Œ≤)ùúáùëûùõΩ\mu(q,\beta).

The subgroup of TransO(Q,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,\langle,\rangle) generated by elementary orthogonal transvections is denoted by ETransO(Q,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,\langle,\rangle).

Definition 4.8.

Let IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. The group of relative orthogonal transvections to an ideal IùêºI is generated by the orthogonal transvections of the form œÉ‚Äã(p)=p‚àí‚ü®u,p‚ü©‚Äãv+‚ü®v,p‚ü©‚Äãuùúéùëùùëùùë¢ùëùùë£ùë£ùëùùë¢\sigma(p)=p-\langle u,p\rangle v+\langle v,p\rangle u, where either u‚ààI‚ÄãPùë¢ùêºùëÉu\in IP or v‚ààI‚ÄãPùë£ùêºùëÉv\in IP. The group generated by relative orthogonal transvections is denoted by TransO(P,IP,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(P,IP,\langle,\rangle).

Definition 4.9.

Let IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. The elementary orthogonal transvections of QùëÑQ of the form œÅ‚Äã(q),Œº‚Äã(q)ùúåùëûùúáùëû\rho(q),\mu(q), where q‚ààI‚ÄãPùëûùêºùëÉq\in IP are called relative elementary orthogonal transvections to an ideal IùêºI.

The subgroup of ETransO(Q,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,\langle,\rangle) generated by relative elementary orthogonal transvections is denoted by ETransO(IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(IQ,\langle,\rangle). The normal closure of ETransO(IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(IQ,\langle,\rangle) in ETransO(Q,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,\langle,\rangle) is denoted by ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle).

Lemma 4.14.

Proposition 4.15.

Let RùëÖR be a commutative ring with R=2‚ÄãRùëÖ2ùëÖR=2R, and let IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. Let (P,‚ü®,‚ü©œÜ)(P,\langle,\rangle_{\varphi}) be an orthogonal RùëÖR-module with PùëÉP free of rank 2‚Äãn2ùëõ2n, n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 and Q=R2‚äïPùëÑdirect-sumsuperscriptùëÖ2ùëÉQ=R^{2}\oplus P with the induced form on ‚Ñç‚Äã(R)‚äïPdirect-sum‚ÑçùëÖùëÉ\mathbb{H}(R)\oplus P. If œÜ=Œµt‚Äãœà~n‚ÄãŒµùúësuperscriptùúÄùë°subscript~ùúìùëõùúÄ\varphi=\varepsilon^{t}\widetilde{\psi}_{n}\varepsilon, for some Œµ‚ààGL2‚Äãn‚Äã(R)ùúÄsubscriptGL2ùëõùëÖ\varepsilon\in{\rm GL}_{2n}(R), then TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ)=ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi})={\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi}).

Proof: Using Lemma 4.11, Lemma 4.12, and Lemma 4.14 we get,

TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ)\displaystyle{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi}) =\displaystyle= (I2‚üÇŒµ)‚àí1TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~n+1)(I2‚üÇŒµ)\displaystyle(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)^{-1}~{}{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{n+1}})~{}(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)
=\displaystyle= (I2‚üÇŒµ)‚àí1‚ÄãEO2+2‚Äãn‚Äã(R,I)‚Äã(I2‚üÇŒµ),superscriptperpendicular-tosubscriptùêº2ùúÄ1subscriptEO22ùëõùëÖùêºperpendicular-tosubscriptùêº2ùúÄ\displaystyle(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)^{-1}~{}{\rm EO}_{2+2n}(R,I)~{}(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon),

and

ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ)\displaystyle{\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi}) =\displaystyle= (I2‚üÇŒµ)‚àí1ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~n+1)(I2‚üÇŒµ)\displaystyle(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)^{-1}~{}{\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{n+1}})~{}(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)
=\displaystyle= (I2‚üÇŒµ)‚àí1‚ÄãEO2+2‚Äãn‚Äã(R,I)‚Äã(I2‚üÇŒµ),superscriptperpendicular-tosubscriptùêº2ùúÄ1subscriptEO22ùëõùëÖùêºperpendicular-tosubscriptùêº2ùúÄ\displaystyle(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon)^{-1}~{}{\rm EO}_{2+2n}(R,I)~{}(I_{2}\perp\varepsilon),

and hence the equality is established. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square

Definition 4.16.

An orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) over the ring RùëÖR is called split if there exists a submodule N‚äÜPùëÅùëÉN\subseteq P such that NùëÅN is a direct summand of PùëÉP and such that NùëÅN is precisely equal to its orthogonal complement N‚üÇ={p‚ààP:‚ü®p,n‚ü©=0‚Äãfor‚Äãall‚Äãn‚ààN}superscriptùëÅperpendicular-toconditional-setùëùùëÉùëùùëõ0forallùëõùëÅN^{\perp}=\{p\in P:\langle p,n\rangle=0~{}{\rm for~{}all}~{}n\in N\}.

Moreover, an orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) over the ring RùëÖR is called locally split if (Pùî™,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P_{\mathfrak{m}},\langle,\rangle) is a split orthogonal Rùî™subscriptùëÖùî™R_{\mathfrak{m}}-module for every maximal ideal ùî™ùî™\mathfrak{m} of RùëÖR.

Lemma 4.17.

(See Lemma 6.3, Chapter I in [9]) Let RùëÖR be a ring such that every finitely generated projective module over RùëÖR is free. Then an inner product space over RùëÖR is split if and only if it possesses a basis so that the associated inner product matrix has the form (0IIA)0ùêºùêºùê¥\big{(}\begin{smallmatrix}0&I\\ I&A\end{smallmatrix}\big{)}. If we also assume that 222 is a unit in the ring, then every split inner product space has matrix (0II0)0ùêºùêº0\big{(}\begin{smallmatrix}0&I\\ I&0\end{smallmatrix}\big{)} with respect to a suitable basis.

Remark 4.18.

In view of Proposition 4.15 and above lemma, for any split orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©œÜ)(P,\langle,\rangle_{\varphi}) over a local ring (R,ùî™)ùëÖùî™(R,\mathfrak{m}) with R=2‚ÄãRùëÖ2ùëÖR=2R, we have TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ)=ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜ){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi})={\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi}). Here IùêºI is an ideal of the ring RùëÖR.

Next we establish dilation principle for relative elementary orthogonal transvection group.

We now establish equality of the orthogonal transvection group and the elementary orthogonal transvection group (in the relative case to an ideal) of a locally split orthogonal RùëÖR-module with R=2‚ÄãRùëÖ2ùëÖR=2R. An absolute version of this result (i.e, when I=RùêºùëÖI=R) was proved in [2] (see Theorem 3.10). Before proving the main result we establish a lemma to show that orthogonal transvections are homotopic to identity.

Lemma 4.21.

Let (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) be an orthogonal RùëÖR-module and Œ±‚ààTransO(P,‚ü®,‚ü©)\alpha\in{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(P,\langle,\rangle). Proof: As Œ±‚ààTransO(P,‚ü®,‚ü©)\alpha\in{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(P,\langle,\rangle), it is product of orthogonal transvections of the form œÑùúè\tau, where œÑùúè\tau takes p‚ààPùëùùëÉp\in P to p‚àí‚ü®u,p‚ü©‚Äãv+‚ü®v,p‚ü©‚Äãuùëùùë¢ùëùùë£ùë£ùëùùë¢p-\langle u,p\rangle v+\langle v,p\rangle u, where u,v‚ààPùë¢ùë£ùëÉu,v\in P are isotropic with ‚ü®u,v‚ü©=0ùë¢ùë£0\langle u,v\rangle=0, and either uùë¢u or vùë£v is unimodular. Define œÑ‚ÄãXùúèùëã\tau X as the map which takes p‚ààPùëùùëÉp\in P to either p‚àí‚ü®u,p‚ü©‚Äãv‚ÄãX+‚ü®v‚ÄãX,p‚ü©‚Äãuùëùùë¢ùëùùë£ùëãùë£ùëãùëùùë¢p-\langle u,p\rangle vX+\langle vX,p\rangle u or p‚àí‚ü®u‚ÄãX,p‚ü©‚Äãv+‚ü®v,p‚ü©‚Äãu‚ÄãXùëùùë¢ùëãùëùùë£ùë£ùëùùë¢ùëãp-\langle uX,p\rangle v+\langle v,p\rangle uX. Theorem 4.22.

Let RùëÖR be a commutative ring with R=2‚ÄãRùëÖ2ùëÖR=2R, and let IùêºI be an ideal of RùëÖR. Let (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) be a locally split orthogonal RùëÖR-module with PùëÉP is of rank 2‚Äãn2ùëõ2n, n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2, and Q=R2‚äïPùëÑdirect-sumsuperscriptùëÖ2ùëÉQ=R^{2}\oplus P with the induced form on ‚Ñç‚Äã(R)‚äïPdirect-sum‚ÑçùëÖùëÉ\mathbb{H}(R)\oplus P. Then TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©)=ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle)={\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle).

Proof: We have ETransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©)‚äÜTransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle)\subseteq{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle). We need to show other inclusion. Let us choose Œ±ùõº\alpha from TransO(Q,IQ,‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle). By Lemma 4.21 there exists Œ±‚Äã(X)ùõºùëã\alpha(X) in TransO(Q[X],IQ[X],‚ü®,‚ü©){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q[X],IQ[X],\langle,\rangle) such that Œ±‚Äã(1)=Œ±ùõº1ùõº\alpha(1)=\alpha and Œ±‚Äã(0)=I‚Äãdùõº0ùêºùëë\alpha(0)=Id. Note that TransO(Qùî™[X],IQùî™[X],‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜùî™)=ETransO(Qùî™[X],IQùî™[X],‚ü®,‚ü©œà~1‚üÇœÜùî™){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],IQ_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi_{\mathfrak{m}}})={\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],IQ_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi_{\mathfrak{m}}}), for each maximal ideal ùî™ùî™\mathfrak{m} of RùëÖR (follows from Remark 4.18). In closing we make Remark 4.24 below for which we need the following elementary observation.

Lemma 4.23.

Let (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) be a split orthogonal RùëÖR-module. Then (Pùî™,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P_{\mathfrak{m}},\langle,\rangle) is a split orthogonal Rùî™subscriptùëÖùî™R_{\mathfrak{m}}-module for every maximal ideal ùî™ùî™\mathfrak{m} of RùëÖR.

Proof: Let us consider an equivalent form of the definition of split orthogonal RùëÖR-modules as it is stated in ¬ß6, Chapter I, [9]. The orthogonal module (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is split if it is direct sum of two submodules MùëÄM and NùëÅN which are dually paired to RùëÖR by the inner product,

M‚ü∂‚âÖHomR‚Äã(N,R),and‚ÄãN‚ü∂‚âÖHomR‚Äã(M,R)formulae-sequencesuperscript‚ü∂ùëÄsubscriptHomùëÖùëÅùëÖsuperscript‚ü∂andùëÅsubscriptHomùëÖùëÄùëÖ\displaystyle M\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cong}}{{\longrightarrow}}{\rm Hom}_{R}(N,R),~{}{\rm and}~{}N\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cong}}{{\longrightarrow}}{\rm Hom}_{R}(M,R)

and such that NùëÅN is self orthogonal, i.e, ‚ü®N,N‚ü©=0ùëÅùëÅ0\langle N,N\rangle=0. Tensoring with Rùî™subscriptùëÖùî™R_{\mathfrak{m}} we get Pùî™=Mùî™‚äïNùî™subscriptùëÉùî™direct-sumsubscriptùëÄùî™subscriptùëÅùî™P_{\mathfrak{m}}=M_{\mathfrak{m}}\oplus N_{\mathfrak{m}}. Moreover, PùëÉP projective will imply both MùëÄM and NùëÅN are projective and hence finitely presented (MùëÄM finitely presented means there exists an exact sequence Rk‚ü∂Rl‚ü∂M‚ü∂superscriptùëÖùëòsuperscriptùëÖùëô‚ü∂ùëÄR^{k}\longrightarrow R^{l}\longrightarrow M, for suitable natural numbers k,lùëòùëôk,l). Therefore, by Proposition 2.13‚Äù in Chapter I, [8] we get

Mùî™‚ü∂‚âÖHomRùî™‚Äã(Nùî™,Rùî™),and‚ÄãNùî™‚ü∂‚âÖHomRùî™‚Äã(Mùî™,Rùî™)formulae-sequencesuperscript‚ü∂subscriptùëÄùî™subscriptHomsubscriptùëÖùî™subscriptùëÅùî™subscriptùëÖùî™superscript‚ü∂andsubscriptùëÅùî™subscriptHomsubscriptùëÖùî™subscriptùëÄùî™subscriptùëÖùî™\displaystyle M_{\mathfrak{m}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cong}}{{\longrightarrow}}{\rm Hom}_{R_{\mathfrak{m}}}(N_{\mathfrak{m}},R_{\mathfrak{m}}),~{}{\rm and}~{}N_{\mathfrak{m}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cong}}{{\longrightarrow}}{\rm Hom}_{R_{\mathfrak{m}}}(M_{\mathfrak{m}},R_{\mathfrak{m}})

Also, NùëÅN is self orthogonal will imply Nùî™subscriptùëÅùî™N_{\mathfrak{m}} is self-orthogonal and hence (Pùî™,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P_{\mathfrak{m}},\langle,\rangle) is a split orthogonal Rùî™subscriptùëÖùî™R_{\mathfrak{m}}-module for every maximal ideal ùî™ùî™\mathfrak{m} of RùëÖR. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square

Remark 4.24.

In view of the above lemma the result as in Theorem 4.22 holds when (P,‚ü®,‚ü©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is assumed to be a split orthogonal RùëÖR-module.
